thread.title: Rick Barnes not happy with goaltend call late at Miss. State
thread.title_full: Rick Barnes not happy with goaltend call late at Miss. State

title: Rick Barnes not happy with goaltend call late at Miss. State
text:
(Photo: USA TODAY Sports) 
STARKVILLE, Miss. --- Rick Barnes waited patiently while the rest of his Tennessee basketball team boarded a bus after Saturday’s 64-59 loss at Mississippi State. 
The second-year Tennessee head coach stuck around to get an explanation from officials, or at least share his opinion, of missed calls during a game in which his team’s 19-point lead melted away Saturday afternoon in front of 7,581 fans at Humphrey Coliseum. 
That was after Barnes had voiced his displeasure with the officiating, one call in particular, during his postgame press conference. 
“I don’t want to take anything away from (Mississippi State),” Barnes said. “A big play, they called Grant Williams for a goaltend and we just saw that it wasn’t a goaltend. 
“We just saw that it wasn’t a goaltend.” 
  
The play occurred with three minutes, five seconds left in the game, Mississippi State leading 57-55. Lamar Peters drove to the rim with Williams in pursuit. 
Tennessee's freshman forward blocked the shot from the backside, pinning the ball against the backboard, but goaltending gave the bucket to Peters and a 59-55 lead to Mississippi State. 
“Instead of being a four-point game, it should have been a two-point game with us with the ball,” Barnes said, “and maybe we could have stopped the momentum.” 
Tennessee led by 19, at 29-10, with 4:50 left in the first half. Mississippi State used an 18-3 run in the second half to get back in the game, as the Vols went over five minutes without a made field goal. 
Xavian Stapleton put the Bulldogs up for good with a 3-pointer with 4:22 left. A Mario Kegler three on the next possession built the lead to four before Admiral Schofield answered in the paint with a bucket, making it 57-55 before the goaltend was called on the other end. 
“That was a big play from us because we were struggling,” Barnes said. “At that point in time, with momentum going their way, you don’t want something like that to happen. 
“I don’t want to take anything away from Mississippi State, but that is disappointing because we did make a great defensive play. We said we needed to get a stop right here, forced them in to drive the ball and (Williams) blocked it. Would have been a shot-clock violation and they got two points out of it.” 
Williams struggled to find words for an answer when asked about the play. 
“It was a play,” Williams said. “It happens. We had to respond to it, and we didn’t.” 
Layups from Bone and Jordan Bowden cut the State lead to 60-59 with 1:05 left, but the Vols didn’t have any answers from there. 
Schofield was called for an offensive foul with 6:43 left, a call that was upgraded to a Flagrant 1 after officials went to the monitor to review the play. 
Barnes didn’t dispute that call. The goaltend was a different story. 
“They said it was an elbow to the face, but I didn’t see it,” he said of the Schofield foul. “They said elbow to the face. I would like to have had more of an explanation of the goaltend. 
“You go to the monitor, you can see an elbow to the face. That one you understand. I don’t think they went to the monitor and got it wrong. An elbow to the face, I have to believe they saw it and got that right. They didn’t get the goal tend right.”
